Injuried Patient Got Denied of Service at your Accredited Hospital


To whom it may concern,

I am a citizen of Hong Kong writing to draw your attention on a recent incidence happened in Hong Kong Adventist Hospital (Tsuen Wan).

Reportedly, a patient was denied of medical attention and service at the Adventist Hospital (Tsuen Wan), after getting injuried in a mass protest in Hong Kong on 12th June 2019. When asked for help, hospital staff requested the injuried patient to leave and allegedly called the Police afterwards, leading to the patient's arrest at Yan Chai Hospital.

When asked, the hospital refused to comment on whether they reported the patient to the Police, but made a statement that the hospital would "not treat patient that got injured due to illegal activities".

Here I must emphasize on the fact that everyone is presumed innocence unless proven guilty in Hong Kong's jurisdiction. And right to health should be a basic human right as stated in Universal Declaration of Human Rights. I also notice that the incidence was a serious infringement of the Declaration of Geneva, where health and well-being should be the first consideration of any member of the medical profession, without taking into account their political affiliation, and certainly not to breach the confidentiality between and violate human rights and civil liberties.

Knowing that the Adventist Hospital (Tsuen Wan) is one of your accredited hospitals, I seek your response regarding to your organization's stance on this issue and whether it represents the value, mission and your accreditation criteria.

A local news report can be found here: http://cablenews.i-cable.com/ci/videopage/news/550993/%E5%8D%B3%E6%99%82%E6%96%B0%E8%81%9E/%E6%A2%81%E5%B0%B1%E5%B8%82%E6%B0%91%E5%B0%8D%E7%95%B6%E5%B1%80%E4%BF%9D%E9%9A%9C%E7%A7%81%E9%9A%B1%E6%9C%89%E7%96%91%E6%85%AE%E8%87%B4%E6%AD%89

I am happy to provide more information if needed.

Yours faithfully,
Linden Chai

Injured Protester Denied of Service at your Accredited Hospital
————

To whom it may concern,

I am writing as a Hong Kong citizen to draw your attention to a recent incident that took place at the Hong Kong Adventist Hospital (Tsuen Wan).

According to a local news report, a protester, who participated in a demonstration in Hong Kong on 12th June 2019, was denied of medical attention at the Adventist Hospital (Tsuen Wan) later that day. The hospital refused to provide medical aid, asked the injured protester to leave and allegedly called the police afterwards, leading to the patient's arrest at another Hospital (Yan Chai Hospital).

The hospital refused to comment on whether they have informed the police or not while being inquired by media. Instead, the hospital issued a statement claiming that the hospital “would not treat patient who are injured due to participation in illegal activities.”

It should be noted that, under Hong Kong's jurisdiction, all suspects are presumed innocent unless that particular individual is found guilty in a trial. Not to mention the fact that the aforementioned protester is not even a suspect at the time he sought medical aid.

The right to health is a fundamental human right enshrined in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. It came to my attention that the incident happens to be a blatant infringement of the Declaration of Geneva, which clearly stated that the patient’s health and well-being should be the first consideration of any member of the medical profession, without taking into account his/her political affiliation. Confidentiality and the respect to human rights should be of utmost importance for all members of any healthcare institution.

Knowing that the Adventist Hospital (Tsuen Wan) is one of your accredited hospitals, your response on this incident is awaited. I urge your organisation to investigate on this matter and to examine if the Hong Kong Adventist Hospital still falls in line with your organisation’s value, mission and accreditation criteria.
